section.title: Configuring Service Providers
section.para: You can configure a service provider in the Spring application context using Spring Social's Spring configuration namespace:
The <social:service-provider> element can be used to configure any service provider in Spring. For example, to configure a Twitter provider:
The consumer-key and consumer-secret attributes specify the key and secret values assigned to your application when you registered it with the provider.

The display-name attribute sets a name that describes the provider in user-friendly terms when referring to the provider in the application's user-interface. This is an optional parameter; if left blank, it will default to the value of the id attribute with the first character capitalized.

The request-token-url, authorization-url, and access-token-url attributes set the URLs that Spring should use when coordinating authorization with the provider. The request-token-url is optional; if left blank, the provider is assumed to be an OAuth 2 provider.

The class attribute specifies the fully-qualified name of the provider implementation. A service provider implementation should implement the ServiceProvider interface or extend either AbstractServiceProvider, AbstractOAuth1ServiceProvider, or AbstractOAuth2ServiceProvider.

section.title: Configuring service providers in RDBMS
section.para: Configuring service providers in Spring configuration is straightforward and very convenient. However, should you need to edit any of the service provider details, you would need to edit the Spring configuration and redeploy your application.

One reason that you may need to edit your service provider details is if you reset your client key and secret. Let's say that those values fell into the wrong hands and some other application out there is posing as your application. Most OAuth providers make it easy to assign a new key/secret pair to applications, voiding the previous pair. But if your service provider is configured in Spring configuration, that means you'll need to make the changes, rebuild your application and then redeploy it.

Optionally, you may choose to configure your service providers externally in a relational database. Spring Social's JdbcServiceProviderFactory can create service providers from configuration details stored in RDBMS.
First, you must have a ServiceProvider table in your database. The following DDL creates a table suitable for use with JdbcServiceProviderFactory:
section.programlisting: create table ServiceProvider (name varchar, displayName varchar not null, implementation varchar not null, apiKey varchar not null, secret varchar, appId bigint, requestTokenUrl varchar, authorizeUrl varchar, accessTokenUrl varchar, primary key (name));
section.para: With the ServiceProvider table in place, you may insert rows to represent each of the service providers your application will interact with. For example, you may insert a row for a Twitter service provider:
section.programlisting: insert into ServiceProvider (name, displayName, implementation, apiKey, secret, requestTokenUrl, authorizeUrl, accessTokenUrl) values ('twitter', 'Twitter', 'org.springframework.social.twitter.provider.TwitterServiceProvider', 'twitter_key', 'twitter_secret', 'https://twitter.com/oauth/request_token', 'https://twitter.com/oauth/authorize?oauth_token={requestToken}', 'https://twitter.com/oauth/access_token');

The constructor takes two arguments. The first is a reference to a JdbcTemplate through which JdbcServiceProviderFactory will access the ServiceProvider table. The second is a reference to an implementation of StringEncryptor that will be used to encrypt/decrypt consumer keys and secrets as they're stored/retrieved from the ServiceProvider table.

To simplify configuration of a JdbcServiceProviderFactory, the Spring Social configuration namespace also offers a <social:jdbc-service-provider-factory> element that can be used instead of the explicit bean declaration:

Here, the jdbc-template attribute refers to a JdbcTemplate bean. Optionally, a string-encryptor attribute may refer to a StringEncryptor bean. However, if string-encryptor is not specified, it will default to a no-op implementation that does no encryption on the key/secret pairs.
